Author: Leong, B; Polonetsky, J
Title: Why Opting Out of Student Data Collection Isn’t the Solution
Abstract Note: In every privacy debate across every industry, the same questions arise about the rights of individuals to “opt-out” of their data being collected or used. So it should come as no surprise that the “when” and “how” of parent and student opt-outs of education data collection or use has become a robust
Notes:
Why Opting Out of Student Data Collection Isn’t the Solution

EdSurge News, March 2015

 

Fair Information Privacy Principles (FIPPs)

  • specify purpose
  • informed consent
  • consent can be implied

Benefits of Data Collection

  • Primary use cases - grades, free lunch, etc.
    • Deprivation of these would harm the essential function of the school

Risks

  • Opting out negatively impacts basic demography
  • Funds are poorly allocated
  • Diversity is misrepresented

 

FERPA protects data decisions for marketing data, publicly available data, sensitive survey data

"Legitimate education policy concerns need to be addressed by fixing these problems for all students, not just the minority who protest by opting out"

 

 

I disagree with the sentiment of this article. Polonetsky sidesteps the fact the the opt-out movement is largely tied to certain standardized tests. This movement has grown because there is little demonstrable evidence that these tests provide useful data. It's not as if parents are calling up schools en mass, refusing to let schools collect grades. He totally misrepresents the issue.

Author: Georgia Tech
Title: Cross Validation
Notes:
Cross-validation

If the model fit for the training set doesn't fit well enough, we may try for a higher order polynomial

But that may lead to overfit data

 

Instead, we should train on the test set?

Creates the same problem -> not generalizable

"The test set is a stand-in for what we don't very well know in the future"

Must assume that training and test sets are both representative

(IDD) Independent, Identically distributed)

Fundamental assumption of learning models

Thus, we create a TEST-TEST Set!

-Cross validation set - a stand-in for the actual test data

 

  1. Split training data into folds
  2. Train on first three folds, test with 4th
  3. Train on last three, test with first,
  4. etc., etc.
  5. The best model with lowest error is the one we go with

Author: Zheng, Alice
Title: Evaluating Machine Learning Models
Abstract Note: Data science today is a lot like the Wild West: there’s endless opportunity and excitement, but also a lot of chaos and confusion. If you’re new to data science and applied machine learning, evaluating a machine-learning model can seem pretty overwhelming...
Notes:
Evaluation Metrics

Classification:
-accuracy - straightforward
-confusion matrix - distinguishes between the cost of misclassification depending on scenario (e.g. weighing false-positives differently from false-negative)
for binary classification, a 2x2 matrix
 -- per class accuracy unweights the classes, compared with a straight accuracy evaluation
-log-loss - when classifier outputs probability of a classification, rather than a binary decision. The formula is awesome.
“Cross entropy incorporates the entropy of the true distribution, plus the extra unpredictability when one assumes a different distribution than the true distribution. So log-loss is an information-theoretic measure to gauge the “extra noise” that comes from using a predic‐ tor as opposed to the true labels. By minimizing the cross entropy, we maximize the accuracy of the classifier.”
-AUC - (ROC - receiver operator characteristic) area under curve. 1 is best

Ranking Metrics
-searches for elements that are relevant, and ranks according to relevance
-also applies to personalized recommendation

-precision-recall
“Precision answers the question, “Out of the items that the ranker/classifier predicted to be relevant, how many are truly relevant?” Whereas, recall answers the question, “Out of all the items that are truly relevant, how many are found by the ranker/classifier?””

precision and recall select the same union of returned by ranker/classifier and relevant sets, but because the sizes of these sets are different, the values are different

F1 score is like an AUC metric for precision-recall values at k

- NDCG (normalized discounted cumulative gain) prioritizes higher ranked items

RMSE - very common
 - average, sensitive to outliers (“mean is not robust”)

MAPE (median absolute percentage)

“Almost correct” predictions may be valuable, and worthy of measure

look out for data skew - where one kind of data is more rare than others (e.g. credit card fraud detection)

Author: Greller, Wolfgang; Drachsler, Hendrik
Title: Translating Learning into Numbers: A Generic Framework for Learning Analytics
Abstract Note: ABSTRACT With the increase in available educational data, it is expected that Learning Analytics will become a powerful means to inform and support learners, teachers and their institutions in better understanding and predicting personal learning needs and performance. However, the processes and requirements behind the beneficial application of Learning and Knowledge Analytics as well as the consequences for learning and teaching are still far from being understood. In this paper, we explore the key dimensions of Learning Analytics (LA), the critical problem zones, and some potential dangers to the beneficial exploitation of educational data. We propose and discuss a generic design framework that can act as a useful guide for setting up Learning Analytics services in support of educational practice and learner guidance, in quality assurance, curriculum development, and in improving teacher effectiveness and efficiency. Furthermore, the presented article intends to inform about soft barriers and limitations of Learning Analytics. We identify the required skills and competences that make meaningful use of Learning Analytics data possible to overcome gaps in interpretation literacy among educational stakeholders. We also discuss privacy and ethical issues and suggest ways in which these issues can be addressed through policy guidelines and best practice examples.
Notes:
A generic framework for learning analytics

***This is a great article***

Learning analytics services in support of educational practice and learner guidance... improving teacher effectiveness and efficiency.

Privacy and ethical issues

What are information retrieval technologies?

Goals:

reduce delivery costs while creating more effective learning experiences, accelerating competence development, and increasing collaboration between learners.

Now it is collected by mining normal user behavior

Thus, data is more likely to reflect "real and uninterrupted user behavior"

Questionnaires are still useful to " highlight possible inconsistencies between user behaviour and user perception (Savage and Burrows, 2007)."

6 Dimensions that LA framework should cover:

Internal limitations, external constraints, instruments, data, objectives, stakeholders

Author: Baker, Ryan S. J. d; Corbett, Albert T.; Roll, Ido; Koedinger, Kenneth R.
Title: Developing a generalizable detector of when students game the system
Abstract Note: Some students, when working in interactive learning environments, attempt to “game the system”, attempting to succeed in the environment by exploiting properties of the system rather than by learning the material and trying to use that knowledge to answer correctly. In this paper, we present a system that can accurately detect whether a student is gaming the system, within a Cognitive Tutor mathematics curricula. Our detector also distinguishes between two distinct types of gaming which are associated with different learning outcomes. We explore this detector’s generalizability, and find that it transfers successfully to both new students and new tutor lessons.
Notes:
Developing a generalizable detector of when students game the system

Ryan S. J. d. Baker · Albert T. Corbett · Ido Roll · Kenneth R. Koedinger
2008

Definition:
“attempting to succeed in an educational environment by exploiting properties of the system rather than by learning the material and trying to use that knowledge to answer correctly” (Baker et al. 2006).

First Gaming detectors 2004

Cognitive Tutor
Uses BKT - Corbett and Anderson 1995

Two types of gaming:
1. quickly asking for help
2. inputting answers quickly and systematically, until student is advanced by the system

The original detector only predicted students who gamed and did poorly, but missed the ones who gamed and had high post test scores

Second model used “leave-out-one-cross-validation”

Field observations based on repeated 20-s behavior observations, conducted using peripheral vision.

normalized timer per actions

Latent response models


Modeling:
Fast Correlation-Based Filtering (Yu and Liu 2003)
Forward Selection (Ramsey and Schafer 1997)

A′ is equivalent to both the area under the ROC curve in signal detection theory, and to W , the Wilcoxon statistic

Author: Desmarais, Michel C.; Naceur, Rhouma
Title: A Matrix Factorization Method for Mapping Items to Skills and for Enhancing Expert-Based Q-Matrices
Abstract Note: Uncovering the right skills behind question items is a difficult task. It requires a thorough understanding of the subject matter and of the cognitive factors that determine student performance. The skills definition, and the mapping of item to skills, require the involvement of experts. We investigate means to assist experts for this task by using a data driven, matrix factorization approach. The two mappings of items to skills, the expert on one side and the matrix factorization on the other, are compared in terms of discrepancies, and in terms of their performance when used in a linear model of skills assessment and item outcome prediction. Visual analysis shows a relatively similar pattern between the expert and the factorized mappings, although differences arise. The prediction comparison shows the factorization approach performs slightly better than the original expert Q-matrix, giving supporting evidence to the belief that the factorization mapping is valid. Implications for the use of the factorization to design better item to skills mapping are discussed.
Notes:
A Matrix Factorization Method
for Mapping Items to Skills and for Enhancing Expert-Based Q-Matrices

Desmarais & Naceur (2013)

Map skills requires subject matter knowledge, definitions, and expert involvement

Assist SME’s using matrix factorization

Linear models:
compensatory models of skills: each skill required adds to the chances of success of an item.

conjunctive models (Barnes, Stampers, et al) - any required skill missing will induce a failure to the item (all skills required)

disjunctive model - any skill is sufficient

Alternate Least Squares Factorization (ALS)
described p 444

For best optimization, begin with expert matrix Q0
“In our experiments, the convergence at a delta of 0.001 occurs after 7–8 iterations and in a fraction of a second for factorizing a matrix of dimension 20×536.”

ALS Method compares the expert matrix with results, and estimates values for each cell using cross validation
This can be rounded to create a new binary matrix, if desired

How much the ALS matrix differs from the expert matrix can be taken as a proxy for the validity of the ALS matrix

Author: Grunspan, Daniel Z.; Wiggins, Benjamin L.; Goodreau, Steven M.
Title: Understanding Classrooms through Social Network Analysis: A Primer for Social Network Analysis in Education Research
Abstract Note: Social interactions between students are a major and underexplored part of undergraduate education. Understanding how learning relationships form in undergraduate classrooms, as well as the impacts these relationships have on learning outcomes, can inform educators in unique ways and improve educational reform. Social network analysis (SNA) provides the necessary tool kit for investigating questions involving relational data. We introduce basic concepts in SNA, along with methods for data collection, data processing, and data analysis, using a previously collected example study on an undergraduate biology classroom as a tutorial. We conduct descriptive analyses of the structure of the network of costudying relationships. We explore generative processes that create observed study networks between students and also test for an association between network position and success on exams. We also cover practical issues, such as the unique aspects of human subjects review for network studies. Our aims are to convince readers that using SNA in classroom environments allows rich and informative analyses to take place and to provide some initial tools for doing so, in the process inspiring future educational studies incorporating relational data.
Short Title: Understanding Classrooms through Social Network Analysis
Notes:
Understanding Classrooms through Social Network Analysis: A Primer for Social Network Analysis in Education Research

Grunspan, Wiggins, Goodreau (2014)

Author: Siemens, George; Baker, Ryan S. J. d.
Title: Learning Analytics and Educational Data Mining: Towards Communication and Collaboration
Publication Title: Proceedings of the 2Nd International Conference on Learning Analytics and Knowledge
Abstract Note: Growing interest in data and analytics in education, teaching, and learning raises the priority for increased, high-quality research into the models, methods, technologies, and impact of analytics. Two research communities -- Educational Data Mining (EDM) and Learning Analytics and Knowledge (LAK) have developed separately to address this need. This paper argues for increased and formal communication and collaboration between these communities in order to share research, methods, and tools for data mining and analysis in the service of developing both LAK and EDM fields.

Author: Corbett, Albert T.; Anderson, John R.
Title: Knowledge tracing: Modeling the acquisition of procedural knowledge
Abstract Note: This paper describes an effort to model students' changing knowledge state during skill acquisition. Students in this research are learning to write short programs with the ACT Programming Tutor (APT). APT is constructed around a production rule cognitive model of programming knowledge, called theideal student model. This model allows the tutor to solve exercises along with the student and provide assistance as necessary. As the student works, the tutor also maintains an estimate of the probability that the student has learned each of the rules in the ideal model, in a process calledknowledge tracing. The tutor presents an individualized sequence of exercises to the student based on these probability estimates until the student has ‘mastered’ each rule. The programming tutor, cognitive model and learning and performance assumptions are described. A series of studies is reviewed that examine the empirical validity of knowledge tracing and has led to modifications in the process. Currently the model is quite successful in predicting test performance. Further modifications in the modeling process are discussed that may improve performance levels.
Notes:
Knowledge tracing: Modeling the acquisition of procedural knowledge
Corbett & Anderson
1995

Knowledge tracing, probabilistic estimate of knowledge

Based on idea that 1) knowledge is arranged hierarchically
2) prerequisites should always be learned before more advanced skills

Key Assumptions:
Two-state learning model: each rule is either learned or unlearned

Rules can transition from unlearned to learned through reading, application, or practice

Rules can not be forgotten - an error can still occur on a learned rule because the learned state is represented as a probabilistic function


Probability states
p(L) -> probability learned
p(Lo) -> initial learning
p(T) -> Acquisition
p(G) -> Guess (correctly)
p(S) -> Slip (incorrect when learned)


“Since the tutor does not accept an incorrect programming action, the student is always on a recognizable solution path”

Assessing validity:
-correlate actual accuracy and predicted accuracy
-compute the mean error in prediction across goals to check whether the model is systematically over or under estimating accuracy
-compute mean absolute error in prediction

by allowing learning an performance parameter estimates to vary across rules, the model reflects aver differences in rule difficulty

see equation 4 for incorporating (p270) for incorporating individual learner differences

Author: Bowers, Alex J.
Title: Analyzing the Longitudinal K-12 Grading Histories of Entire Cohorts of Students: Grades, Data Driven Decision Making, Dropping out and Hierarchical Cluster Analysis
Abstract Note: School personnel currently lack an effective method to pattern and visually interpret disaggregated achievement data collected on students as a means to help inform decision making. This study, through the examination of longitudinal K-12 teacher assigned grading histories for entire cohorts of students from a school district (n=188), demonstrates a novel application of hierarchical cluster analysis and pattern visualization in which all data points collected on every student in a cohort can be patterned, visualized and interpreted to aid in data driven decision making by teachers and administrators. Additionally, as a proof-of-concept study, overall schooling outcomes, such as student dropout or taking a college entrance exam, are identified from the data patterns and compared to past methods of dropout identification as one example of the usefulness of the method. Hierarchical cluster analysis correctly identified over 80% of the students who dropped out using the entire student grade history patterns from either K-12 or K-8. (Contains 5 figures.)
Short Title: Analyzing the Longitudinal K-12 Grading Histories of Entire Cohorts of Students

Author: Cortez, Paulo; Silva, Alice Maria Gonçalves
Title: Using data mining to predict secondary school student performance
Publication Title: Proceedings of 5th Annual Future Business Technology Conference
Abstract Note: Although the educational level of the Portuguese population has improved in the last decades, the statistics keep Portugal at Europe’s tail end due to its high student failure rates. In particular, lack of success in the core classes of Mathematics and the Portuguese language is extremely serious. On the other hand, the fields of Business Intelligence (BI)/Data Mining (DM), which aim at extracting high-level knowledge from raw data, offer interesting automated tools that can aid the education domain. The present work intends to approach student achievement in secondary education using BI/DM techniques. Recent real-world data (e.g. student grades, demographic, social and school related features) was collected by using school reports and questionnaires. The two core classes (i.e. Mathematics and Portuguese) were modeled under binary/five-level classification and regression tasks. Also, four DM models (i.e. Decision Trees, Random Forest, Neural Networks and Support Vector Machines) and three input selections (e.g. with and without previous grades) were tested. The results show that a good predictive accuracy can be achieved, provided that the first and/or second school period grades are available. Although student achievement is highly influenced by past evaluations, an explanatory analysis has shown that there are also other relevant features (e.g. number of absences, parent’s job and education, alcohol consumption). As a direct outcome of this research, more efficient student prediction tools can be be developed, improving the quality of education and enhancing school resource management.
Notes:
USING DATA MINING TO PREDICT SECONDARY SCHOOL STUDENT PERFORMANCE
Cortez and Silver (2008)
Applying EDM to education in Portugal
Models used: decision trees, random forest, neural networks, and support vector machines

Model predicts well, with first and or second school period grades

Author: Matsuda, Noboru; Furukawa, Tadanobu; Bier, Norman; Faloutsos, Christos
Title: Machine Beats Experts: Automatic Discovery of Skill Models for Data-Driven Online Course Refinement
Abstract Note: How can we automatically determine which skills must be mastered for the successful completion of an online course? Large-scale online courses (e.g., MOOCs) often contain a broad range of contents frequently intended to be a semester's worth of materials; this breadth often makes it difficult to articulate an accurate set of skills and knowledge (i.e., a skill model, or the QMatrix). We have developed an innovative method to discover skill models from the data of online courses. Our method assumes that online courses have a pre-defined skill map for which skills are associated with formative assessment items embedded throughout the online course. Our method carefully exploits correlations between various parts of student performance, as well as in the text of assessment items, to build a superior statistical model that even outperforms human experts. To evaluate our method, we compare our method with existing methods (LFA) and human engineered skill models on three Open Learning Initiative (OLI) courses at Carnegie Mellon University. The results show that (1) our method outperforms human-engineered skill models, (2) skill models discovered by our method are interpretable, and (3) our method is remarkably faster than existing methods. These results suggest that our method provides a significant contribution to the evidence-based, iterative refinement of online courses with a promising scalability. [For complete proceedings, see ED560503.]
Notes:
Machine beats experts: Automatic discovery of skill models for data-driven online course refinement

Matsudo, Furukawa, Bier, Faloutsos (2015)


ePIPHANY is a machine learning method to fully and automatically discover skill sets from online course data, by examining problems, feedback text, and student learning interaction data

ePIPHANY is scalable, and outperforms human experts on several datasets

If learning curves don’t move down, there is likely something wrong with the Q Matrix

Author: Kucirkova, Natalia; FitzGerald, Elizabeth
Title: Zuckerberg is ploughing billions into 'personalised learning' – why?
Abstract Note: Zuckerburg wants to plough billions into personalised learning, but his way may not be the right way.
Notes:
Personalized computer based learning environments hold great promise, if they can utilize a diversity of student data types better than teachers already do. It is not enough to merely look at students’ interests or performance; CBLEs will need to integrate social, motivational, and emotional data into their models to really revolutionize education.
Investing billions into a few start-ups now is too soon (and anti-competitive), since there is still a tremendous amount of research to be done. If a company corners the industry before more ideas are tested, the promise of personalized learning may prove to be oversold.

Author: Georgia Tech
Title: Feature Selection
Notes:
Feature selection is useful for

Narrow the number of features by determining which are important

1) Knowledge discovery

- which features matter?

    - interpretability and insight

    - spam filtering might be as easy as filtering messages from Nigerian princes

2) Curse of dimensionality

 - amount of data you need grows exponentially with the number of features

Author: Kay, Judy; Maisonneuve, Nicolas; Yacef, Kalina; Reimann, Peter
Title: The Big Five and Visualisations of Team Work Activity
Abstract Note: We have created a set of novel visualisations of group activity: they mirror activity of individuals and their interactions, based upon readily available authentic data. We evaluated these visualisations in the context of a semester long software development project course. We give a theoretical analysis of the design of our visualizations using the framework from the “Big 5” theory of team work as well as a qualitative study of the visualisations and the students’ reflective reports. We conclude that these visualisations provide a powerful and valuable mirroring role with potential, when well used, to help groups learn to improve their effectiveness.
Notes:
The Big Five and Visualisations of Team Work Activity

Kay, Maisonneuve, Yacef, Reimann (2006)

Contrary to prior assumptions, teamwork does not spontaneously happen
It takes effort

Big Five components of teamwork
1) Team leadership
2) Mutual performance monitoring
3) Backup behavior
4) Adaptability
5) Team orientation

requires
1) shared mental models
2) mutual trust
3) closed loop communication

Visualizations:
Activity radar
-measure participation along a radial axis
the colors are not necessary?

interaction network
-SNA based, examines nodes and edges
-edge thickness measures strength of connections

Wattle Tree
Good idea, but looks like crap in practice
Stupid Australian trees
Should be horizontal, and not yellow :)

These three visualizations can be used to represent teamwork
Automatic Tags: Artificial Intelligence (incl. Robotics); Computers and Education; Information Systems Applications (incl. Internet); Multimedia Information Systems; User Interfaces and Human Computer Interaction
Editor: Ikeda, Mitsuru; Ashley, Kevin D.; Chan, Tak-Wai

Author: Konstan, Joseph A.; Walker, J. D.; Brooks, D. Christopher; Brown, Keith; Ekstrand, Michael D.
Title: Teaching Recommender Systems at Large Scale: Evaluation and Lessons Learned from a Hybrid MOOC
Short Title: Teaching Recommender Systems at Large Scale
Notes:
Teaching Recommender Systems at Large Scale: Evaluation and Lessons Learned from a Hybrid MOOC

Konstan, Walker, Brooks, Brown, Ekstrand (2015)

A MOOC offered on coursera provided several key insights:

effort: best indicator of success

completion hard to predict, but best predictor is intent

“As part of this exploration, we focused extensively on gathering data for research; this course is the first such class we are aware of that supplements student process and outcome data with both a survey of student background/intent and a subject matter mastery pretest/posttest to assess student learning outcomes.”

28,389 students, of whom, 21,357 were active in some way
39 students in the face-to-face section

knowledge, experience, and intent are greatest predictors of completion.

age, sex, language, US residency, nor status as professional or student did not predict completion

Introversion negatively correlated w/ completion

model could not predict final grades
models better predicted grades for procedural knowledge, and less for conceptual knowledge

follow up studies are very difficult for MOOCs, because learners are spread out across the world and it is hard to make general incentives

many students enroll in courses without knowing about the school’s reputation

“Too often, the dominant message from MOOCs is about the large number of students who sign up but do not complete”
-MOOCs are capable of delivering so much rich information about education, even with their large non-completion rates


“Everything is optional” is not an acceptable response when people feel that their grades are important

They claim to value the pickers and choosers, but grades do not reflect this value

What should the role of grades be in MOOCs?

MOOCs incorporation of class data motivates learners - i.e.. movie preferences, etc.

MOOC platforms limited assignment categories make it hard for instructors to create a “culture” of course work, and can lead to confusion
Automatic Tags: learning assessment; Massively Online Open Course (MOOC)

Author: Young, Jeffrey R.
Title: Why Students Should Own Their Educational Data
Publication Title: The Chronicle of Higher Education Blogs: Wired Campus
Notes:
Do not make lesson for average student: this helps no students.

"And doctors would say weird things like, “Oh the treatment didn’t work for you. You must have had an aggressive form of it.” That’s the dumbest thing. All cancer is aggressive."

...Same problem in education.

Personality research helped influence our understanding of personalization in learning:

"Your aggression level, how easygoing you are in the lunchroom doesn’t tell us a lot about how you’ll be in a classroom, believe it or not. But the way you are in that lunchroom is incredibly stable over time"

Reading level impacts performance in all subjects

Center for Individual Opportunity (http://www.projectvariability.org/)

 

The value of MOOCs is that it forces the conversation about the value of education... we must be able to decide what a college education is worth... do MOOCs save money for the same education? Are they a better ROI? How can higher ed institutions learn to adjust their model to learn from/compete with MOOCs?

Author: san Pedro, Maria Ofelia; Baker, Ryan; Bowers, Alex; Heffernan, Neil
Title: Predicting college enrollment from student interaction with an intelligent tutoring system in middle school
Notes:
Predicting College Enrollment from Student Interaction with an Intelligent Tutoring System in Middle School

San Pedro, Baker, Bowers, Heffernan (2013)

College Enrollment from ITS data!?


Limitations in previous studies:
identify disengagement, like failing grades, violence, non-attendance
By the time these indicators appear, it may be to late to intervene.


Feature design -> affect detectors (boredom, engaged concentration, confusion, gaming the system, overall usage)

#Best Algorithms Used for predicting Affect
boredom: K* algorithm
confusion: J48 algorithm
off-task behavior: REP-Tree algorithm
gaming: K* algorithm

Generate aggregate predictor variables (e.g. average boredom)

Good detailed descriptions of models used

Uses RapidMiner

“linear regression functions well with noisy educational data, creating relatively low risk of finding an “over- fit” model that does not function well on new data.”


“in-the-moment interventions provided by software (or suggested by software to teachers) may have unexpectedly large effects, if they address negative affect and disengagement.”

It is super important to eliminate boredom and disengagement as much as possible, because the consequences add up

Always scatter plot data?

giant blobs

one mega point
Heat Maps

State Space Diagrams


State Space Diagrams
Visualizations of all the states that the learning system can have during a problem
State - complete characterization of the situation
also known as student learning pathways or interaction networks
Can be used for a single student, or for all possible student states
Uses
study specify trajectories
see which paths are productive
see which paths are rare
can be used to make recommendations to students based on their path

Title: Cluster
Notes:
k-means Gotchas

Assumes there are clusters
does not work on some shapes
Need uniform scale (uniform variance)
Doesn't work on categorical data (of more than two categories), and the scale may be difficult to interpret
Can get stuck on local minima
Too easy
